Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration and Refugee Board has jurisdiction to hear a refugee claim without the claimant's consent when a two-member panel is required
Legal_Rule: A two-member panel is required for Convention refugee hearings unless the claimant consents to a single member; consent must be clear and unequivocal
Procedural_Issue: Lack of claimant consent for a single-member hearing
Grounds_for_Claim: Jurisdictional violation due to absence of consent
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Violation of procedural requirements under Section 69.1(7)
Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of written or verbal consent from the claimant
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged the Board's jurisdiction due to improper panel composition
Court_Result: Decision overturned, matter remitted for rehearing
Remedy_Requested: Set aside decision, remit for rehearing
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for rehearing by a differently constituted panel
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before a properly constituted panel
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Jurisdictional defect due to lack of consent
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction â€“ Immigration and Refugee Board
Governing_Rule: Section 69.1(7) requires two-member panel unless claimant consents to single member
